perturbation.original_text: 6.3 If either Party to this Agreement fails to perform or violates any material obligation of this Agreement, then, upon thirty (30) days written notice to the breaching Party specifying such failure or violation, the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement without liability, unless: (a) the failure or violation specified in the default notice has been cured within the thirty (30) day notice period; or (b) the failure or violation reasonably requires more than thirty (30) days to correct, and the breaching Party has begun substantial corrective action to remedy the failure or violation within the thirty (30) day notice period and diligently pursues such action, in which event, termination shall not be effective unless sixty (60) days has expired from the date of the default notice without such corrective action being completed and the failure or violation remedied.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.3 If either Party to this Agreement fails to perform or violates any material obligation of this Agreement, then, upon ten (10) days written notice to the breaching Party specifying such failure or violation, the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement without liability, unless: (a) the failure or violation specified in the default notice has been cured within the ten (10) day notice period; or (b) the failure or violation reasonably requires more than ten (10) days to correct, and the breaching Party has begun substantial corrective action to remedy the failure or violation within the ten (10) day notice period and diligently pursues such action, in which event, termination shall not be effective unless fifteen (15) days has expired from the date of the default notice without such corrective action being completed and the failure or violation remedied.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires a 30-day notice period for contract termination due to breach, which is generally acceptable. The modified text reduces this to a 10-day notice period, which may be deemed unreasonably short under Texas law (governing law specified in 9.13), especially for complex breaches requiring substantial corrective action. Courts often evaluate the reasonableness of notice periods based on the circumstances, and 10 days may not provide sufficient opportunity to cure a material breach.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract Laws - Texas (reasonableness of notice period). Principles of contract law regarding adequate opportunity to cure a breach.

perturbation.original_text: 4.3 Each Party shall promptly provide to the other Party a written invention disclosure of each Agreement Invention made by its employees that results directly from the present Agreement for worked performed under the SOWs herein. The other Party agrees to delay making public, by publication or otherwise, until the earlier of (a) the first filing of a patent application claiming the Agreement Invention by the Inventing Party; or (b) six months after the date the Agreement Invention is disclosed to the other Party; or (c) mutual agreement of the Parties that neither will pursue legal protection of an Agreement Invention.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.3 Each Party shall promptly provide to the other Party a written invention disclosure of each Agreement Invention made by its employees that results directly from the present Agreement for worked performed under the SOWs herein. The other Party agrees to delay making public, by publication or otherwise, until the earlier of (a) the first filing of a patent application claiming the Agreement Invention by the Inventing Party; or (b) two months after the date the Agreement Invention is disclosed to the other Party; or (c) mutual agreement of the Parties that neither will pursue legal protection of an Agreement Invention.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows a six-month delay before the other party can make public any invention disclosure. The modified text reduces this to two months. This change introduces a legal inconsistency because it may not provide sufficient time for the inventing party to adequately assess the invention's patentability, prepare and file a patent application, thus potentially jeopardizing their intellectual property rights. This can be considered unreasonable under principles of good faith and fair dealing, especially considering the collaboration involves technology transfer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Law (reasonable time to file a patent application), Principles of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (contract law).

perturbation.original_text: 7.3 Each of the parties agrees that for five (5) years from the date of disclosure, the receiving Party agrees to limit disclosure of the disclosing Party's Confidential Information to those of the receiving party's employees and contractors, and employees and contractors of its Subsidiaries, who have a need to know it, and the receiving Party agrees to use the same care and discretion to avoid disclosure, publication or dissemination outside of those employees and contractors as the receiving Party does with similar information of its own which it does not desire to publish, disclose or disseminate.
perturbation.changed_text: 7.3 Each of the parties agrees that for one (1) year from the date of disclosure, the receiving Party agrees to limit disclosure of the disclosing Party's Confidential Information to those of the receiving party's employees and contractors, and employees and contractors of its Subsidiaries, who have a need to know it, and the receiving Party agrees to use the same care and discretion to avoid disclosure, publication or dissemination outside of those employees and contractors as the receiving Party does with similar information of its own which it does not desire to publish, disclose or disseminate.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states a five-year confidentiality period. Reducing this to one year can be problematic, particularly considering the nature of the agreement involves technology transfer and proprietary information. A one-year period might be considered unreasonably short to protect valuable trade secrets and confidential information, especially in the biopharmaceutical industry where product development cycles are lengthy and competitive advantages rely heavily on maintaining confidentiality for extended periods. This change could be viewed as a breach of the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing if it significantly undermines the disclosing party's interests. Texas courts will examine if this duration provides adequate protection given the specific facts of the industry and transferred information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law (misappropriation), Principles of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (contract law), Texas Uniform Trade Secrets Act (potentially, depending on the nature of the Confidential Information).
